name: Alcuin of York
summary: Alcuin was an English scholar, clergyman, and teacher who became a leading figure in the Carolingian Renaissance. He was invited by Charlemagne to establish a palace school and became one of the most important educators of his time. He wrote on theology, grammar, and education, and helped standardize the Latin liturgy.

name: Charlemagne
summary: Charlemagne, also known as Charles the Great, was King of the Franks and Lombards, and was crowned as the first Holy Roman Emperor by Pope Leo III in 800. He expanded the Frankish kingdom into an empire that covered much of Western and Central Europe. He promoted education, culture, and Christianity throughout his realm, initiating the Carolingian Renaissance. He is considered the father of Europe and one of the most important figures in medieval history.

name: St. Cyril

locations.description: Missionary to the Slavs in Moravia

summary: Cyril, along with his brother Methodius, were Byzantine Greek brothers who became missionaries to the Slavs. They are credited with creating the Glagolitic alphabet, the first alphabet used to transcribe Old Church Slavonic. They translated the Bible and liturgical texts into Slavonic, which helped spread Christianity among Slavic peoples. They are venerated as the Apostles to the Slavs and are co-patrons of Europe.

name: St. Methodius

locations.description: Bishop and missionary to the Slavs in Moravia

summary: Methodius, along with his brother Cyril, were Byzantine Greek brothers who became missionaries to the Slavs. After Cyril's death, Methodius continued their missionary work and became Archbishop of Sirmium. He faced persecution for using Slavonic in the liturgy but was supported by the Pope. He is venerated as the Apostle to the Slavs and co-patron of Europe.

name: St. Ansgar

locations.description: Bishop of Hamburg, missionary to Scandinavia

summary: Ansgar was a Frankish missionary who is known as the Apostle of the North. He was the first Archbishop of Hamburg and worked to convert the Danes and Swedes to Christianity. He faced many hardships, including the destruction of his churches by Viking raids, but persevered in his missionary work. He is the patron saint of Scandinavia.

name: St. Rabanus Maurus

locations.description: Abbot of Fulda, later Archbishop of Mainz

summary: Rabanus Maurus was a Frankish Benedictine monk, abbot, and theologian. He was a student of Alcuin and became one of the most learned men of his time. He served as abbot of Fulda and later as Archbishop of Mainz. He wrote extensively on theology, education, and biblical exegesis, and was a key figure in the Carolingian Renaissance.

name: Pope St. Nicholas I
summary: Nicholas I was Pope from 858 to 867. He is known as Nicholas the Great and is considered one of the most important popes of the 9th century. He strongly asserted papal authority, particularly in conflicts with the Byzantine Empire and the Carolingian rulers. He supported the missionary work of Cyril and Methodius and defended the use of Slavonic in the liturgy.
